para.paratext: One presumption which causes a great deal of discussion involves the spoliation or destruction of evidence. Under Georgia law, a fact presumption arises once it is shown that a party has changed or discarded evidence.[1] The presumption is that the evidence would have been harmful before it was changed or discarded. However, the evidence must have been discarded after a party receives notice that an adverse party is contemplating litigation.[2] The duty to preserve the evidence must be viewed from the perspective of the party with control of the evidence and is triggered not only when litigation is pending but when it is reasonably foreseeable to that party.[3] Thus, “the duty to preserve relevant evidence arises when litigation is reasonably foreseeable to the party in control of that evidence, and thus while actual notice of litigation from the plaintiffs would clearly make such litigation foreseeable, other circumstances may show that the defendant/alleged tortfeasor actually or reasonably should have anticipated litigation, even without notice of a claim being provided by the injured party/plaintiff.”[4]

In Phillips v. Harmon,[5] the Supreme Court rejected the proposition that only actual notice of a claim by the plaintiff triggered the duty of a defendant to preserve evidence. The plaintiffs in this case sued for medical malpractice. The hospital destroyed strips of paper from a fetal heart monitor which contained notes by the nurses, according to policy, despite the severe injuries to the child, and after triggering its Sentinel Events/Medical Errors/Disclosures policies and procedures immediately after the child's birth. The Court stated:

[N]otice that the plaintiff is contemplating litigation may also be derived from, i.e., litigation may be reasonably foreseeable to the defendant based on, other circumstances, such as the type and extent of the injury; the extent to which fault for the injury is clear; the potential financial exposure if faced with a finding of liability; the relationship and course of conduct between the parties, including past litigation or threatened litigation; and the frequency with which litigation occurs in similar circumstances. Thus, it may be appropriate to consider, in determining whether the defendant actually did or reasonably should have foreseen litigation by the plaintiff, not only what the plaintiff did or did not do after the injury and before the evidence in question was lost or destroyed, but also what the defendant did or did not do in response to the injury, including the initiation and extent of any internal investigation, the reasons for any notification of counsel and insurers, and any expression by the defendant that it was acting in anticipation of litigation.[6]
Thereafter, the responsible party is allowed to offer rebuttal testimony explaining what happened to the evidence, and the jury then decides whether the presumption has been rebutted.

In Cooper Tire & Rubber Company v. Koch,[7] the Court of Appeals declined to apply the factors set out in Phillips in a situation where a plaintiff is accused of spoliation. Rather, the court held that “the duty to preserve relevant evidence arises when litigation is reasonably foreseeable to the party in control of the evidence.”[8] The Georgia Supreme Court affirmed this decision and further instructed that “before a remedy for spoliation may be imposed, the party seeking the remedy must show that the allegedly spoliating party was under a duty to preserve the evidence at issue that was then breached.”[9] The Court further explained that the duty to preserve evidence is the same for the plaintiff as for the defendant; however, the practical application of the duty may vary upon the circumstances of each case.

In VIF/Valentine Farms Building One, LLC v. Wright,[10] the Court of Appeals held that where sanctions by the trial court for spoliation of evidence include the dismissal of claims by a party, the dismissal acts an adjudication on the merits, unless the court specifies otherwise.

In Greer v. Andrews,[11] the plaintiff was allowed to introduce letters that she had received from the defendant even though she had cut out and discarded portions of these letters. The Georgia Supreme Court held that it was proper to have admitted the letters and also held that it was proper to have allowed the plaintiff's explanation that she had cut out portions of the letters in order to save storage space. In so holding, the court stated Georgia's spoliation rule: “Spoliation of evidence raises a presumption against the spoliator.”[12]

In a suit for lost profits due to the defendant's failure to make lease payments on rented vehicles, Bennett v. Associated Food Stores, Inc.[13] upheld a directed verdict against the plaintiff because he had destroyed the maintenance records on the rented vehicles, and thus could not show the exact amount of his lost profits. The plaintiff had also testified that he did not know what the destroyed records showed. In its ruling, the court stated “the presumption is that if the destroyed records had been produced they would have disclosed that the cost or certainly the cost plus depreciation, exceeded the mileage collected.” In other words, a specific presumption arose that the evidence which had been destroyed would have shown there were no lost profits.

In Glynn Plymouth, Inc. v. Davis,[14] the plaintiff alleged that her husband had died from a car wreck caused by defective brakes, but the car was not available for testing at the time of trial. The plaintiff explained that she had sold the car to someone in another state after it had been repaired. In this instance, the appellate court held that the spoliation presumption arose against the plaintiff, but upheld the denial of a directed verdict against the plaintiff because a jury question existed; the plaintiff had offered rebuttal expert testimony to the effect that a brake failure had probably caused the wreck.

The presumption arises once it is shown that a party has tampered with evidence. This approach has been described as the “fair process” theory since it compensates innocent adversaries for losses from evidence spoliation regardless of the excuse for the spoliation.[15] Under this approach, “fairness dictates that the party which destroys the evidence should bear the burden of such destruction,”[16] and “the presumption arises even if the destruction of evidence has been in good faith, since the reason for the destruction goes to weight rather than to admissibility.”[17]

Other jurisdictions have applied the fair process approach to the spoliation presumption in medical malpractice cases where portions of medical records are missing due to negligence,[18] for unknown reasons,[19] or where they have been altered.[20] Some jurisdictions presume “consciousness of guilt” from evidence spoliation, but typically allow this more harsh presumption only if there is a showing that the evidence was destroyed with a bad-faith intent.[21] A Maryland court has taken a hybrid approach to the application of the spoliation presumption, holding that the jury should be instructed that various types of presumptions should arise from various levels of intent.[22] Thus, if a party destroys evidence without bad faith intent, a presumption arises that the particular piece of evidence would have been unfavorable to the party. However, if a party has destroyed evidence in bad faith, a presumption would arise that the party had a consciousness of guilt.

American Cas. Co. of Reading, Pa. v. Schafer[23] clarified that Georgia's spoliation presumption is the same regardless of the party's intent when destroying the evidence. The case also stands for the position that the spoliation presumption arises against a party who simply “contributes” to the loss of records. The Georgia Court of Appeals reversed a summary judgment for the defendant because relevant records of the defendant had not been available at the summary judgment stage and the trial court had not made a determination about whether the defendant “caused or contributed to the loss of the subject records.” However, the trial court abused its discretion when it gave a jury instruction on spoliation which allowed an adverse inference to be made against a party where the court made no finding of intentionality, bad faith, or incurable prejudice.[24]

Although the spoliation presumption is most commonly applied in cases involving the destruction of documentary or other evidence known to have existed, it has also been extended to the failure to produce evidence under circumstances where a party would be likely to produce the evidence if it were favorable to his case. For example, in Hankinson v. Rackley,[25] both the plaintiff and the defendant in a conversion action failed to produce receipts or other documents which would have supported their respective claims of ownership. The trial court instructed the jury on the presumption under former O.C.G.A. § 24-4-22 (now O.C.G.A. § 24-14-22), and the Court of Appeals held that it was not error to do so where it would have been the usual practice for the defendant to have obtained a receipt upon purchase and for the plaintiff to have written a list of missing items. The presumption also applies when contradictory responses were given in testimony.[26]

A civil litigant's “apparent initial attempt to hide evidence or avoid discovery” is admissible at trial because this type of conduct raises a presumption the claim against the litigant is “well-founded.” This was the holding of Uniroyal Goodrich Tire Co. v. Ford.[27] Uniroyal argued on appeal that the plaintiff should not have been allowed to tell the jury that Uniroyal had “resisted discovery and hidden evidence of prior deaths and injuries.”[28] Uniroyal first cited Prevost v. Taylor[29] for the proposition that pretrial discovery disputes are irrelevant and inadmissible. Uniroyal next cited O.C.G.A. §§ 9-11-26 et seq. for the proposition that the court and not the jury decides whether a party has complied with discovery and whether to impose sanctions.

The Court of Appeals rejected both arguments, citing former O.C.G.A. § 24-4-22 (now O.C.G.A. § 24-14-22), which states that, when a party fails to produce evidence, a presumption arises that the “charge or claim against him is well founded.”[30] Based on this statute, the court held that “it was not improper to allow the jury to make an adverse inference from Uniroyal's apparent initial attempt to hide evidence or avoid discovery.”[31] Six of eight judges participating in the court's en banc decision joined the holding on the discovery issue.

By clarifying the application of former O.C.G.A. § 24-4-22 (now O.C.G.A. § 24-14-22) to discovery proceedings, the Court of Appeals has provided a strong tool to help stop discovery abuses, especially in product liability and medical malpractice cases, where virtually all of the critical liability evidence must be obtained from defendants. The presumption which arises under former O.C.G.A. § 24-4-22 (now O.C.G.A. § 24-14-22) as the result of an attempt to avoid discovery is different from the spoliation presumption which arises in Georgia from the destruction or alteration of evidence. The spoliation presumption arises regardless of whether the party who destroyed or altered the evidence was acting in bad faith; this is known as the “fair process” theory.[32] The presumption which arises under Uniroyal from an attempt to avoid discovery necessarily arises only in situations involving bad faith because the Uniroyal holding addressed the failure “to produce evidence as required.”[33] Also, spoliation of evidence raises the presumption that the particular piece of evidence, which is no longer available, would have been harmful to the party who destroyed or altered this evidence if the evidence was still available.[34] The presumption which arises against a party who attempts to avoid discovery is that the charge against this party is “well-founded.”[35]

In 1996, the Court of Appeals held that the spoliation presumption does not apply to a situation where a party's subsequent treating dentist repaired dental work in the plaintiff's mouth to prevent infection, bleeding and pain.[36] Although this repair prevented inspection of the previous dental work, which was at issue, the court held it would be improper to apply the spoliation presumption against patients because they received necessary medical treatment.
In 1997, the Court of Appeals twice held that a defendant's failure to comply with O.C.G.A. § 8-2-106(c) is a type of evidence suppression which does raise the spoliation presumption.[37]

In Lane v. Montgomery Elevator Co.,[38] the plaintiff was injured when she fell because she did not realize that the elevator that she was riding in had stopped several inches above the floor where she was exiting. A 6-3 decision of the Court of Appeals reversed a summary judgment order for the defendant because there was evidence the defendant failed to comply with O.C.G.A. § 8-2-106(c), which prohibits using an elevator (or performing maintenance and repair work on an elevator) after the elevator malfunctions and before a required postaccident state inspection. The elevator owner in Montgomery had done both things (meaning evidence had been destroyed). Maintenance records showed that the elevator had experienced a blown fuse in a control circuit several hours after the accident at issue (implying that the elevator was still in service after the accident). Also, records showed that maintenance work was done on the elevator three days after the accident and two days before a state inspection (and, therefore, in violation of the statute). Last, the defendant's records were not even clear about which of several elevators was involved in the accident. Based upon these statutory violations, which had the effect of covering up the status of the elevator at the time of the malfunction, the court said that a jury would have to decide the case.

Ruben's Richmond Dept. Store v. Walker[39] was also an elevator case involving a plaintiff whose foot was caught between the elevator and the floor when the elevator malfunctioned. After the injury, the defendant elevator owner made no report of the elevator malfunction as required, and the Court of Appeals found that the trial court had properly allowed the plaintiff to place in evidence the fact that the defendant had not submitted the required postaccident report (and to show there had not been the required postaccident state inspection). In so holding, the court stated that it was proper to admit such evidence because it raised a rebuttable presumption that an inspection of the elevator would have shown it was not properly maintained.

App. 767, 768, 574 S.E.2d 923 (2002), “Spoliation refers to the destruction or failure to preserve evidence that is necessary to contemplated or pending litigation. And, when key evidence has been destroyed, exclusion of evidence [such as the spoliating party's expert testimony about the missing evidence] or dismissal of a case may be warranted.” In determining whether such a severe sanction is warranted, the trial court must consider (1) whether the non spoliating party was prejudiced as a result of the destruction of the evidence, (2) whether the prejudice can be cured, (3) the practical importance of the evidence, (4) whether the spoliating party acted in good or bad faith, and (5) the potential for abuse if expert testimony about the evidence was not excluded.
